sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The monotypic genus
Dinahia Bechyně, 1946
, endemic to the Atlantic Forest ( Rio Grande do Sul , Santa Catarina , and São Paulo ), is reviewed.
Dinahia privigna Bechyně, 1946
is redescribed, and, for the first time, the aedeagus and spermatheca of this species are described and illustrated herein. Additionally, a diagnosis for the genus, a nomenclatural history, photographs of both non–type specimens and the syntype , a geographic distribution map, and a discussion of
Dinahia
and similar genera according to the bibliography (
Calligrapha Chevrolat, 1836
;
Cosmogramma Erichson, 1847
;
Desmogramma Erichson, 1847
;
Grammomades Achard, 1923
; and
Zygogramma Chevrolat, 1836
) are provided. This discussion incorporates a comparative table encompassing characters extracted from the antennae, maxillary palps, prosternal, mesoventral, and metaventral processes, V tarsomeres, and claws. Additionally, it includes an illustrated replacement couplet for step 22 in
identification key, both to elucidate
Dinahia
's differentiations and similarities from these five genera.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Dinahia
is a monotypic genus that is scarcely known and rarely collected. It was described by Bechyně in 1946 based on only two specimens of
Desmogramma ståli Jacoby, 1903
, which is currently considered synonymous of
Dinahia privigna ( Stål, 1859 )
as per
. Even 77 years following its description, no new species have been added to the genus, and it has been exclusively reported from Brazil , specifically in the states of Rio Grande do Sul , Santa Catarina , and São Paulo (
;
). As such, it is considered an endemic genus of the Atlantic Forest.

According to
, due to the enlarged last maxillary palpomeres,
Dinahia
is similar related to
Cosmogramma Erichson, 1847
,
Polyspila Hope, 1840
(currently considered synonymous with
Calligrapha Chevrolat, 1836
),
Desmogramma Erichson, 1847
, and
Zygogramma Chevrolat, 1836
. At the same time, it is distinguished by the presence of an abruptly emarginate labrum, non–projected base of the prosternal process, and tarsomere V lacking spiniform ventroapical projection. However, a comprehensive description of the genus, its species, and genitalia has never been provided.

The objective of this paper is to review the monotypic genus
Dinahia
.This entails presenting a diagnosis of the genus, offering a redescription and illustrations of the external morphology of
D . privigna
, and, for the first time, providing a description and illustrations of the aedeagus and spermatheca of this species. Additionally, the paper also aims to provide a geographic distribution map and engage in a discussion about possible relationships between
Dinahia
and the five similar genera according to the bibliography (
Calligrapha
,
Cosmogramma
,
Desmogramma
,
Grammomades
, and
Zygogramma
). This discussion includes a comparative table encompassing characters extracted from the antennae, maxillary palps, prosternal, mesoventral, and metaventral processes, V tarsomeres, and claws. Moreover, the paper incorporates an illustrated replacement couplet for step 22 in
identification key, with the purpose of clarifying the distinctions and similarities of
Dinahia
in relation to these five genera.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Ten specimens and photographs of the
D . privigna
syntype from the following institutions were examined: Museu de Zoologia da Universidade de São Paulo , São Paulo , Brazil ( MZSP ), Museo del Instituto de Zoología Agrícola Francisco Fernández Yépez, Maracay, Venezuela ( MIZA ), and Museum für Naturkunde der Humboldt–Universität, Berlin , Germany ( ZMHB ).

For the dissection, the specimens were initially placed in a moist chamber for 24 hours to facilitate preliminary softening. Subsequently, their abdomens were carefully detached using tweezers and stylets. Following that, the detached abdomens were immersed in a 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution for up to ten minutes to ensure complete softening of both tissues and exoskeleton. After this step, they were neutralized using acetic acid and rinsed with 70% alcohol. Subsequently, the genitalia were removed and preserved in microtubes filled with glycerin, and the abdomens were reattached to the specimens.

In the nomenclatural history, references are presented in the following format: author, year of publication, and page number the taxon is cited. The following abbreviations are utilized: cat. (catalog), cit. (citation), check. (checklist), descr. (description), distr. (geographical distribution), redescr. (redescription), and syn. (synonym).

In the geographical distribution, as obtained in
, countries are represented with capital letters, and states are underscored. The format for presenting the examined data is as follows: country (in uppercase); state (underscored); city (in italics).

Measurements (length and width) are given at the beginning of the redescription. Body length was measured in dorsal view, from the anterior margin of the clypeus to the apex of the elytra. The width was measured from the widest point of the elytra.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Dinahia Bechyně, 1946: 124
(descr.); 1952: 26 (cat., distr.).

Type species
:
Dinahia privigna ( Stål, 1859 )
, by monotypy.

Diagnosis : Reddish brown, light brown, and/or dark brown body, with yellowish or light brown elytra with eight reddish brown and dark brown stripes, arranged longitudinally. Prosternal process with a keel extending from base to apex; short and slightly oblique mesoventral process; prominent metaventral process with rounded margins. Aedeagus with lateroventral plate ventrally invaginated in the apical region, convex ventroapical region, emarginate apical end, and endophallus with long, curved flagellum, enlarged at the apex. Spermatheca with laterally inserted spermatic duct, wavy and usually medially curled.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Chrysomela privigna
;
Stål, 1865: 187
(distr., redescr.).

Type locality
: Brazil
.

Redescription : Body length: 7.1 – 7.9 mm ( ♂♂ ), 8.0 – 9.2 mm ( ♀♀ ); body width: 4.9 – 5.7 ( ♂♂ ), 6.0 – 6.5 ( ♀♀ ). Reddish brown, light brown and/or dark brown head, with or without 1–2 dark brown spots, featuring a subtle metallic green reflection. Scape, pedicel, antennomeres III–VI, as well as maxillary and labial palps yellowish, light brown and/or reddish brown; antennomeres VII–XI dark brown. Reddish brown mandibles, with the apex and part of the ventral region dark brown or black. Reddish brown and/or light brown pronotum, with one or more dark brown or black spots that may extend across almost the entire surface, accompanied by a subtle yellow or metallic green reflection. Reddish brown scutellum. Yellowish or light brown elytra with eight stripes: three reddish browns, one along the sutural margin extending generally from the base near the scutellum to the apex; and two interspersed in the median region, extending from the anterior third near the base to the posterior third near the apex. Additionally, five dark brown stripes with a slight metallic green reflection: one adjacent to the sutural margin, extending from the anterior third near the base to the posterior third close to the apex; three interspersed within the median region, spanning from the anterior third near the base to the posterior third near the apex; and one along the outer margin, extending from the humeral region to the posterior third close to the apex. Yellowish, light brown and/or reddish brown epipleura. Reddish brown, light brown, and/or dark brown ventral region and legs.

Head (
, 11, 18) with fine and abundant punctuation. Oblong eyes. Antennomeres III–VI with short and sparse bristles; antennomeres VII–XI enlarged, slightly flattened, and with short and abundant bristles.Antennomere III, 1.7–1.8x the length of antennomere IV. Clypeus with medially acuminate frontoclypeal suture. Labrum with long and sparse bristles, and its apical emarginate margin. Robust mandibles, with, sparse punctuation, and long, sparse bristles. Maxillary palpomere III subconical and 1.5–1.6x the length of palpomere IV. Labial palpomere III elongated with truncated apex.

Thorax (
–5, 8–12, 15–17, 18, 19, 24, 25) with prothorax with slightly rounded lateral margins. Pronotum with thick and abundant punctuation. Prosternal process with longitudinal keel, extending from the base to the apex, thick and sparse punctuation, and long, sparse bristles. Mesoventrite with coarse and sparse punctuation, and long, sparse bristles. Additionally, a short, slightly oblique process positioned just below the metaventral process. Metaventrite with fine and sparse punctuation, and prominent process with generally rounded margins.

Legs (
, 9, 16, 25) moderately robust, with fine, sparse punctuation, and short, sparse bristles; apical half of the tibia (ventral and lateral regions) with short, abundant bristles. Tarsomere V without spiniform ventroapical projection. Simple claws.

Elytra (
, 8–10, 15–17, 24, 25) with 11 longitudinal rows of fine and/or thick punctures extending from the anterior third, near the base, to or in proximity to the apex, delineating the stripes; excluding the row adjacent to the sutural margin, which is limited to the anterior quarter. Surface generally with disordered punctures in the yellowish parts and inside the stripes. Epipleura devoid of bristles.

Abdomen (
, 9, 16, 25) with fine, sparse punctuation, and short, sparse bristles; last abdominal sternite with rounded apex.

Aedeagus (Figs. 20–23) symmetrical, elongated, sclerotized, and wavy. Basal lobe almost continuous with the median lobe. Median lobe, in lateral view, obtusely curved in the anterior third. Oblong apical orifice and generally with creases present up to the base of the ligule. Convex ventroapical region.Apical extremity slightly curved in lateral view, dorsally flattened, and with emarginate tip. Endophallus with long, curved flagellum, widened at the apex.

Spermatheca (Figs. 6, 7, 13, 14) short, sclerotized, and hook–shaped. Cornu strongly curved, with same width as median region, apex rounded, and the internal angle obtuse. Elongated nodulus. Spermatic duct thin, long, inserted laterally, wavy and curled medially.
Sexual dimorphism : Maxillary palpomeres IV of males are slightly wider than those of females.

Distribution : BRAZIL – Rio Grande do Sul : Bento Gonçalves and Marcelino Ramos; Santa Catarina : Florianópolis (São João Batista do Rio Vermelho), Seara (Nova Teutônia), and Timbó; and São Paulo : Cantareira and Salesópolis ( Bechyně, 1952 ; Bechyně & Bechyně, 1965 ).

sec.title: Remarks and comparative notes
sec.p:
Little is known about the potential relationships of
Dinahia
with other genera of Doryphorini.To establish an accurate phylogenetic placement of
Dinahia
, a comprehensive phylogenetic analysis involving all genera constituting this tribe is indispensable. Nonetheless, morphological features suggest a similarity relationship between
Dinahia
and certain genera within the Doryphorini.

As previously mentioned,
considered the genus
Dinahia
to be similar related to
Calligrapha
,
Cosmogramma
,
Desmogramma
, and
Zygogramma
, based on the last enlarged maxillary palpomeres. Furthermore,
also considered that
Dinahia
can be distinguished from other genera by the abruptly emarginate labrum, the absence of a spiniform ventroapical projection on tarsomere V , and the base of the non–projected prosternal process. However, all these characteristics used by
to differentiate
Dinahia
can be found in other genera of Chrysomelinae .

recently published an illustrated key encompassing nearly all genera found in Brazil . In this key,
Dinahia
will key to in the same couplet ( 22 in
) as
Grammomades Achard, 1923
, based on the prominence of the metaventral process in relation to the mesoventral process. Furthermore, this key also illustrates that
Dinahia
differs from
Grammomades
by the presence of a longitudinal keel on the prosternal process. Despite the key being specific to genera occurring in Brazil ,
Dinahia
can be distinguished from other Neotropical genera by the combination of characters specified in the diagnosis.

As previously elucidated by
, to attain a comprehensive understanding of the genera within Chrysomelinae , characterized by considerable similarities, it is imperative to conduct a meticulous examination of the intrinsic characters of the antennae, palps, prosternal, mesoventral, and metaventral processes, as well as structures like tarsi and claws. This necessity arises from the observation that these structures predominantly manifest gender distinctions in external morphology.

Hence, to enhance clarity and dynamism in elucidating the similarities and distinctions between
Dinahia
and similar genera found in Brazil , we present a table ( Table 1 ) illustrating the presence and absence of specific characters derived from the structures mentioned by
. Consequently, the features considered in this context are those found in
Dinahia
, such as: maxillary palpomeres IV enlarged in relation to maxillary palpomeres III – Character 1 (Fig. 29); maxillary palpomeres IV with straight apical margin – Character 2 (Fig. 29); antennomeres IX–X as long as wide or wider than long – Character 3 (Fig. 30); base of prosternal process not projected – Character 4 (Fig. 31); prosternal process with a longitudinal keel – Character 5 (Fig. 31); metaventral process more prominent than mesoventral process – Character 6 (Fig. 31); tarsomere V without a spiniform ventroapical projection – Character 7 (Fig. 32); and divergent claws – Character 8 (Fig. 32). The analysis of genital characters was not explored due to a lack of material for comparison.

According to Table 1 ,
Calligrapha
shares similarities with
Dinahia
in characters 3 (Fig. 34), 4 (Fig. 35), 5 (Fig. 35), and 8 (Fig. 36).
Cosmogramma
in characters 1 (Fig. 37), 4 (Fig. 39), 5 (Fig. 39), and 8 (Fig. 40).
Desmogramma
in characters 2 (Fig. 42), 7 (Fig. 44), and 8 (Fig. 44).
Grammomades
in characters 2 (Fig. 45), 4 (Fig. 47), 6 (Fig. 47), 7 (Fig. 48), and 8 (Fig. 48).
Zygogramma
in characters 1 (Fig. 49), 3 (Fig. 50), 4 (Fig. 51), and 5 (Fig. 51).

Concerning the distinctions,
Calligrapha
exhibits distinctions in characters 1, 2, 6, and 7. Specifically, it showcases maxillary palpomeres IV as wide as or slightly narrower than maxillary palpomeres III (Fig. 33), maxillary palpomere IV with slightly oblique apical margin (Fig. 33), metaventral process as prominent as mesoventral process (Fig. 35), and tarsomere V with one spiniform ventroapical projection (Fig. 36).
Cosmogramma
, differs in characters 2, 3, 6, and 7. It presents maxillary palpomere IV with slightly oblique apical margin (Fig. 37), antennomeres IX–X longer than wide (Fig. 38), metaventral process as prominent as mesoventral process (Fig. 39), and tarsomere V with two spiniform ventroapical projections (Fig. 40).
Desmogramma
displays distinctions in characters 1, 3, 4, 5, and 6. It features maxillary palpomeres IV as wide as or slightly narrower than maxillary palpomeres III (Fig. 41), antennomeres IX–X longer than wide (Fig. 42), base of prosternal process projected, usually forming a nearly straight angle (Fig. 43), and prosternal process with or without longitudinal depression (Fig. 43), and metaventral process as prominent as mesoventral process (Fig. 43).
Grammomades ,
in relation to characters 1, 3, and 5, has maxillary palpomeres IV as wide as or slightly narrower than maxillary palpomeres III (Fig. 45), antennomeres IX– X longer than wide (Fig. 46), and prosternal process with a longitudinal depression (Fig. 47). Lastly,
Zygogramma
is differentiated by characters 2, 6, 7, and 8. It has a maxillary palpomere IV with slightly oblique apical margin (Fig. 49), metaventral process as prominent as mesoventral process (Fig. 51), tarsomere V with one spiniform ventroapical projection (Fig. 52) and converging claws (Fig. 52).

Thus, it becomes apparent that
Grammomades
shares a larger set of characters with
Dinahia
when compared to these five genera. Therefore, despite the results presented herein in terms of similarity, for a more precise delineation of relationships between
Dinahia
and other genera, it would be essential to conduct a phylogenetic analysis that ideally encompasses all genera within Doryphorini, incorporating a significant number of characters derived from various other structures, encompassing both external and internal morphology.

Consequently, for a more comprehensive understanding of the distinction between
Dinahia
and
Grammomades
, we present an illustrative replacement couplet for step 22 in
identification key. This couplet incorporates a greater number of characters, including some compiled from this paper, to facilitate discrimination between these two genera.

sec.title: Replacement couplet for Sampaio & Fonseca's identification key (2023)
sec.p:
22 (21) – Non–metallic body, reddish brown, or light brown with dark brown spots on the head and pronotum, and yellowish or light brown elytra with reddish brown and dark brown stripes ( Figs. 1–4 , 8–11, 15–18, 24, 25); maxillary palpomeres II shorts, generally smaller than maxillary palpomeres III (Fig. 29); antennomeres IX–X as long as wide or wider than long (Fig. 30); pronotum slightly convex and with dense punctuation ( Figs. 4 , 11, 18, 24); elytra with both ordered and disordered punctuation ( Figs. 1 , 8, 15, 24), prosternal process with a longitudinal keel (Figs. 5, 12, 19, 31)...........................
Dinahia
.

– Body almost entirely metallic, black, dark brown, and light brown, with light brown spot on the vertex, and black elytra with light brown stripes (Figs. 27, 28); maxillary palpomeres II longs, usually the same size as maxillary palpomeres III (Fig. 45), pronotum strongly convex and with fine punctuation (Fig. 27), elytra with exclusively ordered punctuation (Fig. 27), prosternal process with a longitudinal depression (Fig. 47).................................................
Grammomades
.
